rocks.notes: Highly porous and fragile; even small amounts of recent rain weaken holds. Avoid climbing until rock feels completely dry, cracks may stay damp for several days.
Tougher than sandstone but still porous; wetting can damage edges and slopers. Shaded or sheltered faces retain moisture longer.
Moderately porous; dries faster but damp cracks and pockets reduce friction and protection reliability. Inspect before climbing.
Dense and fine-grained; dries reasonably quickly but can become very slippery when wet. Layered surfaces may delaminate if climbed wet.
Brittle, soft rock; moisture reduces friction and can erode small features. Avoid climbing after rain until surface is dry and chalk has returned.
Very low porosity; surface dries quickly. Shaded cracks or depressions may hold water, so check for slick spots. Generally safe sooner than sedimentary rocks.
